args:
With their workshop moved to the Halidom,
the blacksmith sisters have but one regret:
They have yet to resolve things with their rival,
a rokkan blacksmith named Lazry. To finish the
matter, the sisters decide to forge a sword for
entry in the Golden Anvil competition.
Some time after the three blacksmith sisters\nrelocate their workshop to the Halidom...

...Okay, that's the one hundred arrows 
that you ordered. Don't imagine there'll
be any issues there, but look 'em over
and make sure you're happy.
Ha! You gals are next-level fast as always.
We're very fortunate you agreed\nto join us here at the castle.
Have you gotten used to life here yet?\nPlease be sure to let me know if you\nrun into any problems.
Hee hee! Nah, we're all right as rain.\nRight, ladies?
Yeah, I suppose? I mean, it's safe here,\nand we've got plenty of work, so...
Hmm? Now, now, don't go fibbing,\nRamona.
Huh?! What are you talking about?\nI'm not... I mean, I'm just...
You know, I hear Lazry is entering the\nGolden Anvil competition.
She's a rokkan blacksmith and somethin'\nof a... Well, call her a professional rival.

A rokkan? Damn! Everyone knows they're
the best smithies around—I wouldn't
wanna go toe-to-toe with them in a
business, I tell ya what.
Tell me about it—we were CONSTANTLY\nbleeding customers to her workshop.\nIt was sooooo annoying.
Even though Dad's techniques are\nWAY better than hers—or anyone's!
Yeah, so I guess I DO sorta have an\nissue, now that I think about it.
I mean, I don't regret movin' the shop,\nbut I DO regret leavin' things unfinished\nwith Lazry.
But now I know what to do: We're gonna\nenter the Golden Anvil and whip her up\nbut good!
Thanks for tellin' me about Lazry, Rena.
Anything for my adorable baby sister.
Well, if we're gonna enter this thing,\nwe'd better have a killer weapon ready!
Maybe we go with a battle-axe?\nSomethin' that big is sure to stand out.
Plus, its size means it takes serious\nheat and muscle to make a good one.\nIt's a good test of smithing fundamentals.
I think we should forge a blade.\nSuch sharp edges and gorgeous finishes\nare the fundamentals of blacksmithing.

If we're all worried about ＂fundamentals,＂
then we totally should make a dagger.
Daggers are the BEST. A smith who can't
make a dagger is no smith at all!
It's like they say: ＂He who laughs at the\ndagger, cries by the dagger!＂
Well, in any case, the three of you want\nto compete by showing off your mastery\nof the fundamentals, right?

Yep—which means making some flashy
stabber with a buncha bells and whistles
just to please the crowd is the wrong way
to go about things.
Renee is right. You only get top quality\nby devotin' yourself to the fundamentals.
That's the legacy we inherited from Dad.
Well then, what kind of weapon\ndid your father specialize in?
Hell, Dad could make ANYTHING—\nbut I guess he was at his best when\nhe was workin' on a good sword.
Indeed. Dad's swords were strong,\ngorgeous, and keen as a razor's edge.
Then forge a sword to make him proud\nand enter it in the Golden Anvil.
That will prove once and for all that\nyou're his worthy successors!
Er, did I say something wrong?
There's no better goal for us than\nforgin' a sword to make Dad proud.
'Cause if we're gonna be the best smiths\naround, we can't just follow in Dad's\nfootsteps—we gotta SURPASS him!
Don't just talk about ＂surpassing＂\nDad like that, Renee!
Come now, we'll need that kind of energy\nand confidence to make a sword worthy\nof the Golden Anvil!
Right then, listen up! Here's what I\nthink the sword should look like...
Nah, that'll never work. I think we\nshould try somethin' more like...
Ooo, I can't wait to see what we make!
